original_data.question: A 45-year-old African-American male presents to the family medicine physician to assess the status of his diabetes. After reviewing the laboratory tests, the physician decides to write the patient a prescription for miglitol and states that it must be taken with the first bite of the meal. Which of the following bonds will no longer be cleaved when the patient takes miglitol?

model_response:
Miglitol is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that reversibly and noncompetitively inhibits the enzymes in the brush border of the small intestine that are responsible for the breakdown of complex carbohydrates to simple carbohydrates. By inhibiting the breakdown of complex carbohydrates to simple carbohydrates, miglitol decreases the postprandial rise in plasma glucose levels. The phosphodiester bonds in the DNA double helix are cleaved during DNA replication. Cystine bonds are found in the keratin of nails and hair. Hydrogen bonds are found in the structure of DNA and RNA. Glycosidic bonds are found in carbohydrates.

Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Denotes a person of African ancestral origins whose family settled in America.
A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
Those physicians who have completed the education requirements specified by the American Academy of Family Physicians.
A condition or state at a particular time.

An article or book published after examination of published material on a subject. It may be comprehensive to various degrees and the time range of material scrutinized may be broad or narrow, but the reviews most often desired are reviews of the current literature. The textual material examined may be equally broad and can encompass, in medicine specifically, clinical material as well as experimental research or case reports. State-of-the-art reviews tend to address more current matters. A review of the literature must be differentiated from HISTORICAL ARTICLE on the same subject, but a review of historical literature is also within the scope of this publication type.
Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Directions written for the obtaining and use of PHARMACEUTICAL PREPARATIONS; MEDICAL DEVICES; corrective LENSES; and a variety of other medical remedies.

A desoxynojirimycin derivative and inhibitor of alpha-glucosidase with antihyperglycemic activity. Miglitol binds to and inhibits alpha-glucosidase, an enteric enzyme found in the brush border of the small intestines that hydrolyzes oligosaccharides and disaccharides into glucose and other monosaccharides. This prevents the breakdown of larger carbohydrates into glucose and decreases the rise in postprandial blood glucose levels. Compared to acarbose, miglitol is systemically absorbed.
A constituent administrative district of a nation.
A wound inflicted by the teeth or fangs of an individual or animal.
Any of the occasions for eating food that occur by custom or habit at more or less fixed times.
In animals, the social relationship established between a male and female for reproduction. It may include raising of young.
A split or indentation in something.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.

A desoxynojirimycin derivative and inhibitor of alpha-glucosidase with antihyperglycemic activity. Miglitol binds to and inhibits alpha-glucosidase, an enteric enzyme found in the brush border of the small intestines that hydrolyzes oligosaccharides and disaccharides into glucose and other monosaccharides. This prevents the breakdown of larger carbohydrates into glucose and decreases the rise in postprandial blood glucose levels. Compared to acarbose, miglitol is systemically absorbed.
